questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician because of a painful swelling above his buttocks for 1 week. He is unable to sit for extended periods because of the pain. He has obstructive sleep apnea and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His only medication is metformin. He appears anxious. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 114 kg (251 lb); BMI is 37 kg/m2. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 96/min and blood pressure is 124/86 mm Hg. Examination shows facial acne. A cyst is seen above the natal cleft. There is tenderness to palpation at the cyst and surrounding tissue. The skin around the cyst is warm and erythematous. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Tract curettage
Coccygectomy
Surgical resection and secondary wound closure
Incision and drainage
Retinoid therapy
Surgical resection and primary wound closure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tract curettage can be considered in patients with chronic or recurrent pilonidal sinus, whereas this patient presents with his first episode of an acute pilonidal cyst, in which a different treatment should be tried first.

B) INCORRECT:

Indications for a coccygectomy include sacrococcygeal germ cell tumors and complications of abdominal perineal resections. Sacrococcygeal germ cell tumors are malignancies of fetuses and infants, not adults. Moreover, a coccygectomy is not necessary to treat a pilonidal cyst, which is a local soft tissue process.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgical resection is the treatment of choice for chronic or recurrent pilonidal cysts. Secondary wound closure is associated with a lower likelihood of disease recurrence, but slower wound healing and prolonged inability to work compared to primary wound closure. However, surgical resection is not indicated in this patient, as he presents with an acute disease course (one week) and this is his first episode.

D) CORRECT:

Incision and drainage is the first step in management of acute pilonidal cyst and required to abate the inflammatory process and alleviate pain. Wounds are usually packed with gauze, and healing occurs by secondary wound closure. Definitive treatment for recurrent pilonidal disease (∼ 50% of cases) involves radical en bloc resection of the inflamed tissue with either primary or secondary wound closure.

Pilonidal disease is more common in patients that are obese, male, have excessive body hair, a deep gluteal cleft, and/or a sedentary lifestyle.
Image Description:

An infected pilonidal cyst (i.e, pilonidal abscess) with localized swelling and reddening is visible on the upper part of the natal cleft.

E) INCORRECT:

Retinoid therapy can be attempted in patients with hidradenitis suppurativa (acne inversa), which is a localized inflammatory process that primarily affects intertriginous areas containing apocrine glands such as the axillae, groin, inner thigh, perineal and perianal areas. Hidradenitis suppurativa usually manifests with multiple nodules or draining sinuses in these areas unlike the single cyst above the gluteal cleft seen here. Retinoids are not used to treat pilonidal disease.
Image Description:

Multiple suppurative lumps and erythema in the axilla. Intertriginous skin is a classic site of predilection.

F) INCORRECT:

Surgical resection is the treatment of choice for chronic or recurrent pilonidal cyst. Primary wound closure is associated with faster wound healing and shorter hospital stays, but has a higher likelihood of disease recurrence than secondary wound closure. However, surgical resection is not indicated in this patient, as he presents with an acute disease course (one week) and this is his first episode.
questions.hint: The presence of a tender, erythematous cyst above the natal cleft, associated low-grade fever, is indicative of acute pilonidal disease.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male driver presents with buttock pain and swelling that have worsened over 48 hours. Examination shows a tender, fluctuant mass with surrounding erythema located 5 cm superior to the anus, slightly lateral to the midline. Small midline openings are noted in the same region with minimal drainage. Digital rectal examination is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Acute pilonidal abscess
Anorectal abscess
Hidradenitis suppurativa
Infected epidermoid cyst
Gluteal furuncle

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – An acute fluctuant mass with erythema and midline pits with drainage in the characteristic location superior to the anus strongly raise suspicion for pilonidal disease with acute abscess formation.

B) INCORRECT:

Anorectal abscesses are located near the anus. This patient's findings are located in the upper gluteal cleft area, making this diagnosis less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Hidradenitis suppurativa typically manifests with multiple recurring lesions in apocrine gland-bearing areas and does not characteristically have the midline pits seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Infected epidermoid cysts typically manifest as painful, erythematous, fluctuant masses, but they characteristically have a central black punctum rather than this patient's midline pits.

E) INCORRECT:

Furuncles occur at the site of hair follicles and typically manifest as tender papules or pustules with possible drainage from follicular orifices, but they do not characteristically have the midline pits seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 31-year-old male patient presents with a 4-day history of increasing pain and swelling in his upper gluteal cleft. He works as a long-haul truck driver and has a history of pilonidal disease treated with drainage 8 months prior. Physical examination shows a 3-cm fluctuant mass lateral to the midline with surrounding erythema and purulent drainage. Vital signs are normal, and he appears well. After performing incision and drainage with a lateral incision, what is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Discharge with wound care instructions only
Schedule CT imaging to evaluate for complications
Refer to surgery for definitive management
Admit for intravenous antibiotics and observation
Prescribe oral antibiotics and arrange primary care follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discharge with wound care alone is insufficient after drainage of a pilonidal abscess. Definitive management is necessary to prevent further recurrence.

B) INCORRECT:

CT imaging is typically reserved for complex pilonidal disease to determine the extent and rule out complications. After successful drainage of a simple abscess, imaging is not routinely indicated.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- After incision and drainage of a simple pilonidal abscess, surgical referral for definitive pilonidal cyst management is indicated to prevent recurrence. This step is particularly important in patients with recurrent disease. Definitive surgical treatment can significantly reduce the risk of future episodes.

D) INCORRECT:

Admission is not indicated for simple pilonidal abscess after successful drainage in a well-appearing patient with normal vital signs. This condition can be managed on an outpatient basis with appropriate follow-up.

E) INCORRECT:

While antibiotics may be considered as adjunctive therapy in some patients, another step is essential to address the underlying pilonidal disease and prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male college student presents to the urgent care clinic with 4 days of worsening pain at the top of his buttocks. He reports difficulty sitting comfortably and noticed some mild swelling yesterday, which has now become more pronounced and tender. He has no significant past medical history and takes no regular medications. On examination, his temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). There is a 4 cm, exquisitely tender, erythematous, and fluctuant mass located in the superior gluteal cleft. A small amount of purulent discharge is expressed from a midline pit. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Ultrasound of the sacrococcygeal area
Application of warm compresses and sitz baths
Prescription of oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
Referral to general surgery for sinus tract excision
Incision and drainage of the abscess

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound can be a useful tool to differentiate between cellulitis and a drainable abscess when the physical exam is equivocal. However, in this case, the mass is clearly described as fluctuant, which is the clinical sign of a fluid collection. Therefore, imaging is unnecessary, provides no additional information that would change management, and would delay the urgent management.

B) INCORRECT:

Warm compresses and sitz baths can provide symptomatic relief and are sometimes used to encourage drainage of a very small, superficial abscess or in cases of early inflammation without a formed abscess. For a 4 cm, well-established, fluctuant abscess with systemic signs like fever, these conservative measures are inadequate and will delay necessary treatment, potentially allowing the infection to worsen.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics are often indicated for skin and soft tissue infections, especially with systemic signs like fever. However, antibiotic therapy alone is insufficient for a walled-off, fluctuant abscess. Antibiotics may be considered as an adjunct following initial management but are not the primary treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical excision of the pilonidal sinus tract is the definitive treatment to prevent recurrence. However, this is an elective procedure performed once the acute infection and inflammation have resolved. Performing a wide excision in an acutely infected field is contraindicated as it increases the risk of wound dehiscence, poor healing, and infection spread.

E) CORRECT:

The definitive initial treatment for any cutaneous abscess is incision and drainage. This procedure relieves pain, removes the nidus of infection, and promotes healing. While antibiotics may be considered as an adjunct due to the patient's fever and surrounding cellulitis, they are not a substitute for mechanical drainage. Definitive surgical management of the underlying sinus tract is deferred until the acute infection has resolved.
questions.hint: This patient has an acute pilonidal abscess, a localized collection of pus arising from an infected pilonidal sinus. The key physical exam finding is a fluctuant mass.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male college student presents to the urgent care clinic with a 4-day history of severe pain at the top of his buttocks. The pain has progressively worsened, making it difficult for him to sit comfortably. He reports spending long hours studying for final exams. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 124/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 4-cm, tender, erythematous, and fluctuant mass in the superior gluteal cleft. A small amount of purulent material is expressed from a midline pit within the mass. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Incision and drainage of the abscess
CT scan of the sacrum and coccyx
Oral cephalexin for 10 days
Wide excision of the pilonidal sinus tract

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The definitive and most appropriate initial management for most uncomplicated cutaneous abscesses is incision and drainage. This procedure immediately relieves the pressure and pain by evacuating the purulent material. After drainage, the cavity is typically packed with gauze to allow for healing by secondary intention. Antibiotics are generally not necessary unless there is significant surrounding cellulitis or the patient is immunocompromised. Definitive surgical excision of the sinus tract may be considered later to prevent recurrence.

B) INCORRECT:

A pilonidal abscess is a clinical diagnosis based on history and physical examination. The findings of a tender, fluctuant mass with a draining pit in the gluteal cleft are characteristic. Imaging is not necessary for diagnosis and would delay definitive treatment. A CT scan might be considered in atypical cases or if there is suspicion of a deeper infection, such as osteomyelitis, but this is not suggested by the clinical presentation.

C) INCORRECT:

While a pilonidal abscess is a bacterial infection, antibiotics alone are insufficient treatment for a walled-off, fluctuant collection of pus. Antibiotics may be indicated for significant surrounding cellulitis, systemic signs of infection, or immunocompromised status, none of which are present in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Wide excision of the sinus tract is a definitive surgical procedure to prevent the recurrence of pilonidal disease. However, it is not the appropriate initial management for an acute abscess. Performing an excision in an acutely infected and inflamed field carries a high risk of wound infection and poor healing.
questions.hint: The presence of a tender, erythematous, and fluctuant mass in the gluteal cleft suggests an acute pilonidal abscess.
